Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Do negative plant-soil feedbacks outweigh positive ectomycorrhizal mutualisms in dipterocarp rainforest?
Award.AbstractNarration:
High tree species diversity is a characteristic feature of rainforests in South America, Africa and Southeast Asia. However, it continues to be difficult for ecologists to explain how such a large number of species can be different enough to coexist when they all use the same small set of resources (light, water, nutrients). Theoretically, only a few dominant competitors should persist. One hypothesis explaining this conundrum is that soil fungi cause seedlings to die as tree populations grow, thus preventing any one species from becoming much more common than any other species. Current research on this topic is promising but has two primary shortcomings. First, it has largely been limited to Central and South American rainforests, despite fundamental differences in soil fungi around the world. Second, it has not considered that some soil fungi benefit, not harm, seedlings. In this project, investigators will take advantage of a rare mass seeding event in Malaysian Borneo to establish experiments that will test hypotheses about positive plant-fungal interactions in this ecologically under-explored part of the world. The work has great potential to lead to new insights into the ecological processes that shape the astounding diversity of tropical rain forests.

In addition to improving our ecological understanding of the maintenance of tropical biodiversity, the insights gained through this research will help conserve the critically endangered rainforest ecosystems of Southeast Asia. Although these rainforests harbor a major share of global biodiversity and play a critical role in the function of the global biosphere, the region is experiencing alarming rates of deforestation. By studying the factors that impact seedling recruitment, this research will provide important knowledge required for successful reforestation and restoration of degraded forests. In addition, the study will shed light on the little known and potentially at risk microbial dimensions of biodiversity in these rainforests. Finally, this work will provide invaluable training for graduate students at US universities to work in a very complex ecosystem and increase US capacity to engage in these ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High tree species diversity is a characteristic feature of tropical rain forests in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. However, it has been difficult for ecologists to explain how such a large number of species can coexist together when they compete for only a small number of resources (that is, light, water, nutrients). Under such conditions only a few dominant competitors should persist. One potential hypothesis explaining this conundrum is that interactions with antagonistic organisms, such as pathogenic soil fungi, strongly reduce the survival and growth of young tree seedlings as seedling populations increase, which prevents any tree species becoming over-dominant. However, not all soil microorganisms are detrimental: many, such as mycorrhizal fungi, form mutualistic relationships that increase tree survival and growth. Current research on such plant-soil feedbacks is promising, but has been limited to Latin American rain forests.  Moreover, this research has not adequately accounted for the effects of beneficial interactions with symbiotic organisms that could lead to greater dominance of some groups of tree species, a pattern more typical of Southeast Asian rain forests.

Funding from the NSF RAPID program enabled us to take advantage of a rare and unpredictable mass flowering event in a tropical forest of Malaysian Borneo that produced sufficient seeds of many tree species to establish field and greenhouse experiments.  These experiments tested key hypotheses about how plant-soil-microbe interactions influence forest diversity in an understudied, yet species-rich, geographic region (Southeast Asia) and explicitly examined the role of soil microbial mutualists on seedling survival and growth. Our results suggest that the negative effects of soil microbes on plant growth are weaker in this Bornean forest than has been documented in forests of other tropical regions, highlighting the importance of expanding the geographic range of research on plant-soil feedbacks. Second, we found that positive interactions with microbial mutualists play an important role in plant-soil interactions. Specifically, we found that tree species hosting mutualistic ectomycorrhizal fungi experience more beneficial plant-soil feedbacks when they are growing in soil near individuals of the same species or closely related species. Importantly, this pattern was different for tree species hosting a different type of mycorrhizal mutualist, arbuscular mycorrhizae: for these species, there was no difference in the plant-soil feedbacks regardless of evolutionary relatedness: their growth was similar whether they were growing in soil near individuals of closely or distantly related species. Our findings are the first to demonstrate that the strength and direction of plant-soil feedbacks depends on the type of mycorrhizal symbiosis. The differences in these plant-fungal interactions may partly explain why ectomycorrhizal tree species have significantly more spatially aggregated seedling distributions than do arbuscular mycorrhizal species in Southeast Asian forests.  Our research will lead to important insights into the role of soil microbial diversity in controlling tree species diversity in tropical forests.
